Worrying excessively about health symptoms (relatively straightforward)
Persistent worry about various life aspects

flaw_patterns.name: projection
flaw_patterns.description: Attributes own feelings or motives to others

flaw_patterns.name: seeking_reassurance
flaw_patterns.description: Wants to be told it's fine rather than exploring

flaw_patterns.name: forgetting_prior_insight
flaw_patterns.description: Returns to old pattern despite earlier realization

exchanges.user: work has been a mess. been there 15 years and suddenly feels like they're looking to replace me. younger people getting the good projects. im probably paranoid but its hard not to think about it. anyway made an appointment with my doctor about the chest thing im worried about. probably nothing but its been bugging me.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work paranoia:** 15 years is a long tenure—that history matters, even if it doesn't feel like it right now. The shift you're noticing (younger people getting projects) could be real, or it could be your mind filling in gaps when you're already feeling shaky. Either way, the fear is real. What would help you tell the difference between "I'm seeing a pattern" and "I'm spiraling"? One thing that might help: track it for a week. When you notice something that feeds the "they're replacing me" story, write down what actually happened versus what your mind says it means. Sometimes seeing it on paper makes the pattern clearer—or shows you it's not as solid as it feels.

**The chest thing:** Glad you made the appointment. That's the right move—let your doctor rule out anything physical. It's been bugging you, you're getting it checked, that's good judgment.

**"What's the point":** That line worries me a little. When you say "what's the point," what are you referring to—pushing for projects? Staying at the job? Something bigger? That kind of hopelessness can make it hard to see options. Let's not close doors yet. You've been there 15 years—that's not nothing. But if your mind is already writing the ending, it's going to be hard to show up in a way that changes the story. What would need to happen for you to feel like there's still a path forward here?

exchanges.assistant:
**"What's the point":** Got it—not dramatic, just realistic about feeling like the decision's already made. That makes sense. But here's the thing: if you act like it's already decided, it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy. You stop advocating for yourself, you pull back, and then they do see you as checked out. I'm not saying the restructuring is in your control—it might not be. But how you show up in the next week is. What would it look like to act as if there's still a chance, even if you're not sure there is?

**Your mom's response:** "That's just how corporations work" is technically true and also completely unhelpful when you're the one sitting in the uncertainty. She's trying to reassure you, but it lands as dismissive because she's not the one waiting to find out if her job is safe. The part about eating and sleeping though—she noticed something real. You're up at 3am, stomach's off, not eating well. That's your body under sustained stress. It's not just "in your head." When we're in fight-or-flight for days on end, sleep goes first, then appetite, then everything else starts to fray.

One thing that might help while you wait for Friday: when you wake up at 3am, don't fight it. Your mind is trying to solve an unsolvable problem (you can't know the outcome yet), so it loops. Instead of lying there spinning, try this—get up, go to another room, write down every single fear your mind is offering. Don't analyze, just dump it all out for 10 minutes. Then go back to bed. Sometimes the brain just needs to feel heard before it'll let you rest. Worth trying?

**Doctor appointment Tuesday:** Glad it got moved up—that's good. And yes, you're probably overthinking it, but also: you won't know until Tuesday, so of course your mind is filling in the gaps. That's what minds do with uncertainty. The chest thing could be anxiety (very common), or it could be something else, and either way the doctor will help you figure it out. You're doing the right thing by getting it checked. Try to hold "I don't know yet" instead of letting your mind run the worst-case scenario on repeat.

**Friday's news:** That's the real deadline. Between now and then, you're in limbo, and limbo is brutal. You can't control what they decide, but you can control how you take care of yourself while you wait. Sleep, food, and not letting your mind run unchecked at 3am—those are the things in your control right now. Let's focus there first.

Your nervous system has been running on high alert for weeks (work uncertainty, sleepless nights, constant vigilance), and your body is doing exactly what bodies do under sustained threat—it's activating the stress response. The tightness, the stomach issues, the sleep disruption—that's all your system trying to protect you. It's not broken. It's doing its job, just in overdrive because the threat (restructuring, job uncertainty) hasn't resolved yet.

So yes, it's anxiety. But that doesn't mean it's not real or that you're doing something wrong. It means your body needs the threat to pass (or needs you to find a way to turn down the alarm) before it can settle. You're not manufacturing this—you're responding to something genuinely stressful.

**Waiting for the email:** An hour out and your manager keeps walking past your desk. Here's what might help right now, in this final hour: notice what your body is doing. Are you holding your breath? Clenching your jaw? Shoulders up by your ears? You're not trying to stop the anxiety, just to remind your system that you don't have to solve this yet. The answer is coming. You can let your body rest until it does.

And after you read it—whatever it says—come back here. We'll figure out the next step together.

exchanges.assistant:

You're all processing the same event from different positions (you kept your job, they lost friends/workload increased/trust got shaken). It'll take time for that tension to settle.

**Jake helping you:** That's useful data. You built a story about him (younger guy taking your opportunities), and now he's showing up differently (actually collaborative, helpful on a client call). Doesn't mean your earlier fear was baseless—you were working with limited information and high stakes. But it does mean the story was incomplete. He might not be your competition. He might just be someone doing his job. Worth updating your read on him.

**Sleep and eating:** This is significant. 3am wake-ups gone, stomach settling, actually eating breakfast—your nervous system is coming back online. The threat passed, and your body is returning to baseline. That's how it's supposed to work. You were in crisis mode for two weeks, and now you're not. Let yourself notice that shift. It's evidence that the anxiety wasn't some permanent broken thing—it was a response to circumstances, and when circumstances changed, it resolved.

**Asking for projects—the back and forth:** Here's what I'm hearing: "Intellectually I know you're right, but what if I ask and they say no?" That's fear talking. Specifically, fear of confirmation—if you don't ask, you can tell yourself "I could have gotten it if I'd asked." If you do ask and they say no, then you have to sit with "they don't see me that way." That's scarier, because it makes the rejection real instead of hypothetical.

But let's test that fear. What actually happens if you ask and they say no? You feel bad for a bit, yeah. But you also know where you stand. And you've signaled that you want more—which matters, because managers aren't mind readers. If you never ask, they assume you're content. If you ask and they say no, at least you've put it on the record that you're interested in growth. That's not nothing.

Now flip it: what happens if you don't ask? You keep your head down, stay "safe," avoid the risk of hearing no. But six months from now, when someone else gets the project, you'll be right back here: "Why didn't they pick me? I've been here longer. I guess they don't value me." And you won't know if it's because they don't value you or because you never told them what you wanted.

"They want to keep me so that's enough right?"—Is it? You're the only one who can answer that. If you're genuinely satisfied doing what you're doing, then yes, it's enough. But if part of you wants more (and it sounds like part of you does, given you've been asking for that client project for months), then "keeping my head down" isn't enough. It's just safe.

What would it look like to ask in a way that feels lower-risk? Maybe not "I need this project," but "I'm interested in doing more client-facing work, especially [specific type]. Are there opportunities coming up where that'd be a fit?" That's not demanding—it's expressing interest and asking for information. They can say yes, no, or "not right now but let's revisit." All of those are useful answers. And none of them are catastrophic.
